keywords: Sample collection, Adult abundance, Age distribution, Biological parameters, ESU/DPS viability
abstract:
The method described in the text aims to estimate the age composition of adult salmon and steelhead trout populations for conservation assessment. This is important because understanding the age distribution helps determine the health and viability of fish stocks. NOAA, a US government agency, suggests documenting various biological parameters annually, such as adult abundance, age distribution, sex ratio, length, and run timing at the population, major grouping, and Endangered Species Unit (ESU) or Distinct Population Segment (DPS) levels for each listed species.

By collecting scale samples from adult fish, scientists can determine their age based on growth rings in their scales. This information provides valuable insights into the population's structure, including the proportion of young and old fish, and thus contributes to a better understanding of the overall health of the population.

The necessity of this method lies in its role in demonstrating the viability of Endangered Species Units (ESUs) or Distinct Population Segments (DPSs). The documentation of age composition, along with other biological parameters, is crucial for effective conservation planning and ensuring the recovery of endangered fish populations.

In summary, the method of estimating age composition through scale sampling is a critical tool in assessing the health and viability of salmon and steelhead trout populations. By understanding the age structure of these populations, conservationists can make informed decisions on population management and recovery efforts.
